awd_titl_txt: Efficient Unconventional Computing with Adaptable Memory Circuit Elements
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to develop novel approaches to massively-parallel computing via utilization of memory circuit elements - resistive, capacitive and inductive devices with a memory feature. A network of memory circuit elements will be used as a core of a specialized processor suitable for an efficient solution of different graph theory optimization problems.  A significant advance in the computation power will be achieved due to a massively-parallel network dynamics in which all network components are simultaneously involved in the calculation. This project will focus on designing of massively-parallel processors based on memory circuit elements, developing algorithms for such processors and their simulation.

Intellectual Merit 
This project will develop a fundamentally new massively-parallel platform and algorithms for efficient solution of certain graph theory optimization problems. It will also advance the state-of-the art for models of memory circuit elements.

Broader Impact
Massively-parallel computing based on adaptable memory circuit elements shows promise for extremely fast solution of different optimization problems having numerous applications in such diverse fields as topology, robotics, traffic optimization, and psychology. the research results, their publication and presentation at conferences, as well as an interdisciplinary training of the next generation of scientists will contribute to ensure the national leadership in advanced technology.

por.por_cntn:
The performed research has advanced the fields of unconventional computing, nonlinear dynamics, electrical engineering and physics of emergent electronic devices with memory. The ultimate goal was to explore novel approaches to in-memory computing (memcomputing) based on networks of emergent memory devices that store and process information on the same physical platform. Emergent memory devices, such as memristors and memcapacitors, adjust their state to input signals and provide analog capabilities unavailable in standard circuit elements, resulting in adaptive circuitry, and providing digital and analog massively-parallel computation.

The comprehensive research program involved the theoretical investigations of nonlinear dynamics of memory networks, development of algorithms and device models, as well as some experimental studies. In particular, the necessary criteria for practical implementation of memcomputing were identified and various possibilities for its practical realization were developed, for instance, based on two-dimensional memristive networks, which are especially useful to find solutions of various graph theory optimization problems. The experimental component consisted in the development of memory device emulators and demonstrations of some novel applications of emergent memory structures.

 

The project results have been broadly disseminated to the research community and the general public. The PI and his group have published about 20 journal papers and several book chapters, and given numerous talks at international conferences, workshops and seminars. Two graduate students, one undergraduate student and one postdoc were involved in the project and trained in this cutting-edge interdisciplinary research field.
